Award.AwardTitle: Inuit Collaborative Workshop in Preparation for the Smithsonian Exhibit, Narwhal, Inuit and Ice in a Changing Artic, 2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a workshop and community meetings in Pond Inlet, Nunavut, Canada Fall 2015 to solicit ideas and advice from Inuit community members for a planned "Narwhal: Inuit and Ice in a Changing Arctic" exhibit at the Smithsonian Museum of Natural History planned for July 2017. The exhibit was envisioned as the capstone of the community outreach plan for a previously funded Arctic Social Science research award "Using Inuit Qaujimajatuqangit, Traditional Knowledge, To Guide The Development Of Hypotheses On Narwhal Tusk Function."

The Fall 2015 workshop includes elders and hunters (some of whom collaborated on the science project), community leaders, Inuit organizations, educators, scientists, and Smithsonian support staff to discuss a variety of themes for the proposed exhibit. In addition, meetings will be held with Hamlet Assembly representatives and the Hunters and Trappers Organization of Pond Inlet. The proposed Themes for the exhibit to be discussed include how natural scientists and Inuit community members collaborate to expand their knowledge of narwhal anatomy, physiology, behavior, and the Arctic; how narwhals are changing and adapting as their environment changes and how these changes are affecting local people who depend on the narwhal for food and folklore; and a final theme that would examine how people from Inuit, European, and Asian cultures have created artwork, legends, and folklore representing how they have understood narwhals through time, including up to the present.

To ensure that Inuit voices are an integral part of the construction of the exhibit, members of the Pond Inlet community will be approached to participate on a review panel of Inuit representatives to work with the exhibit team in order to ensure accuracy and Inuit perspectives Members of the Pond Inlet Hunters and Trappers Organization will also be invited to participate as reviewers for the traditional knowledge of the narwhal and its presentation in the exhibit. In addition, their will be meetings between scientists and local artists, who will be contracted to represent pictorial and art renderings of indigenous hunting, narwhal behavior, and the Inuit legend of the narwhal to be included in the exhibit. The final part of the workshop will be youth-focused in order to elicit information and ideas that will appeal to indigenous children in the Arctic, as well as extend to other indigenous cultures around the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several members of the Smithsonian Institution’s exhibits team for the National Museum of Natural History’s upcoming exhibit, “Narwhal: Revealing an Arctic Legend,” traveled to Pond Inlet in the northern High Arctic of Baffin Island, Canada, to talk with community members and exchange information about the exhibit presentation and inclusion of Inuit perspective. Initiating an open dialog between Inuit community members and the exhibit team allowed for more personal viewpoints, including input on local community members’ lives, their relationship with the narwhal, and lifestyle changes made in response to the impacts of climate change. Meetings with government representatives, land claims representatives, Pond Inlet organizations, selected elders and hunters, and school-based programs were the focus of the field team visit. Informal meetings, workshops and organized children’s groups led by team members were all part of creating long-lasting ties and establishing trust between these groups. Video and audio recordings were captured during the visit, and were used as background materials and a source for direct quotes within the exhibit.

In addition, preliminary arrangements were made for two local hunters to travel to and participate in the Arctic Crashes symposium held later at the Smithsonian. Conversations with the archivist at the Pond Inlet library allowed access to archival materials, and helped establish links to check the accuracy of Inuktitut script within the exhibit text. Discussions with the government assembly representative from Nunavut provided a unique perspective on the interactions between the Canadian government, the territory of Nunavut and Pond Inlet community, describing the political, economic and social implications of a rapidly changing community dynamic. A dialogue with the Hunters and Trappers Management board chairman and the director of the Hunters and Trappers Organization opened the door for continued conversations with the exhibits team members, allowing an opportunity for the exhibit to include quotes and perspectives directly from local organizations and community members.

This field work created a pathway for Inuit participation in a major world exhibit, and a chance for their voices to be heard in broad debates about narwhal biology, Inuit knowledge, and the changing arctic ecosystems. The most important outcome of this community visit was the reinforcement of a lasting and broad relationship for both Smithsonian exhibits team members and Pond Inlet community participants. Such a meaningful relationship has translated to a personal attachment and established an accuracy and legitimacy to the museum approach in describing this community and its reverence for and dependence on the narwhal to a wider audience.
